awd_titl_txt: A Seamless Integration of Communications, Networks, Distributed and Hierarchical Control for Reliable Conversion of Ocean Wave Energy to Electricity
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar radiation produces wind which, when it blows over the ocean surface, generates waves. These waves can travel very long distances with little energy loss. Most importantly, these waves are a source of clean energy readily available for harvesting using appropriate wave energy converters such as oscillating water column converters. Currently, most ocean wave energy conversion projects deal with design, development and testing of single wave energy converters. This research project proposes a vision of a large-scale wave energy conversion park which is capable of generating the electrical power of a large power generating plant. To achieve this goal, a wave energy converter park can be designed as a large intelligent system with intra wave energy converters communication, supervisory global control, and active local control to maximize clean electrical energy generation. The main benefit from the application of the ideas herein proposed is a significant increase in year-round electricity productivity. In fact, it can be shown that hydrodynamic active control as proposed in this research project could increase annual energy conversion productivity by a factor in the range of 1.5 to 2.8.

Most wave energy converters absorb energy by means of an oscillatory motion that makes waves which constructively and/or destructively interfere with the incoming waves. A wave energy converter with fixed geometry and mass possesses a natural period, and it is known that the energy absorption from the sea is largest when the natural period agrees with the wave period, namely at resonance. When this is not the case, a passive wave energy converter has a natural response that is not optimal. This means that there is a possible motion other than the natural one that would absorb more energy. Specifically, in terms of sinusoidal waves and oscillations, there exist optimal values of phase and amplitude of the natural response which could be matched by the wave energy converter using optimal control. Hence, an optimal active control of the primary conversion system can be devised so that the electricity production can be maximized. In essence, what active control can do is to use the machinery in a purposeful way to change the dynamical resistance and mechanical reactance felt by the waves when they act upon the wave energy converter. Therefore, the proposed research will develop new active control techniques which will modify the motion of a wave energy converter closer to one or both of these parameters using both local and global wave climate information gathered by a network of sensors deployed on the wave energy park and other sources such as National Data Buoy Center.

por.por_cntn:
This project demonstrated the feasibility of generating clean renewable electrical power at a larger scale than previously achieved by other researchers in the field of ocean wave energy conversion to electrical energy utilizing real-life models of several wave energy converters (WECs). This project was unique in the sense that it brought together several disciplines to maximize electrical power generation. Specifically, a distributed sensor network was used to measure wave height and velocity profile, which was wirelessly transmitted to the downstream WECs, in order to generate the appropriate control signals that maximize wave energy capture.

The project faced many technical and scientific challenges that had to be overcome. First, we used artificial intelligence techniques such as deep learning to optimally deploy the WECs in the sense of minimizing the ocean surface area occupied by them and yet minimizing the hydrodynamic interaction between devices. The reason being that such interactions can either enhance or reduce the amplitude of the wave experienced by a WEC. An extremely important issue we had to deal with during this process was the difficulty of mathematically modeling the hydrodynamic interactions between devices so that the dimensionality of the model could be kept at a manageable level, in order to design a practical automatic control algorithm which was essential in the maximization of the energy capture of the WECs. In the end, it was determined that a hexagonal configuration with WECs deployed at the corners and at the center was the most robust with respect to wave angles of arrival ranging from ? 60 degrees to + 60 degrees. Most importantly, we demonstrated that the size of the WEC array can be increased by replicating the hexagon configuration with minimal loss of accuracy when dealing with a very large number of devices.

To demonstrate the feasibility of our approach, we used the mathematical model of a production-size prototype oscillating water column WEC currently being tested off the Portugal coast by researchers at the Polytechnic University of Lisbon with whom our research group collaborated throughout the project. This WEC uses a high-efficiency unidirectional air turbine that serves as the prime mover of either an alternating current or a direct current generator. A sketch of the WEC is shown in the figure below.

Herein we designed and applied local nonlinear model predictive control algorithms as well as a global hierarchical control algorithm that was applied to the entire WEC array whose purpose was to monitor the health of all WECs and pass that information to the local controllers. In this project we also developed a hybrid simulation in the laboratory that assessed the performance of this WEC. Specifically, the control algorithm was implemented in software and a prototype of the power electronics were implemented in hardware.

The framework developed by this research will provide the foundation for future research and development in the field of clean renewable energy utilizing the vast resource of ocean waves. Designers will benefit tremendously when considering other types of WECs that will be designed in the future and that may be more robust and efficient than oscillating water column types, as our methodology can be easily adapted new, yet to be designed devices.

We expect that our research results will have a broader impact beyond the field of wave energy conversion to electricity, as many other fields of science and engineering can apply our multidisciplinary approach to solve future problems that are critical to the betterment of society.
